commit.message:
Rename tag for colour patterns w/writing&graffiti

Since writing and graffiti are differentiated now.

Add still more graffiti message options.

A few more things don't need to be signed, a wording tweak, and more on
the Orb of Zot and other things.

Add more graffiti message options.

They shouldn't always be signed anymore.
Add clarifying comment.

Rarely mention graffiti in decor messages.

And add the appropriate hooks so it works.

It currently only shows up on peaceful blue and sparkling fountains.

Restructure coloured writing/graffiti a bit.

So that they can reuse some text, and so there can be a few more
graffiti options.
Add a few more colour names to the database.

Allow randomly named graffiti authors (again).

Now it should work, since @RANDGEN@ works with all monster names.

Allow substitutions in monster names.

Similarly to how we allow them for monster shouts and monster speech,
but much simpler. It currently only substitutes @RANDGEN@ with a name
randomly generated by make_name()

Accordingly, the minor hack substituting RANDGEN with a name randomly
generated by make_name(), and only for steelspirits, has been removed
and replaced with this method.
Fix some spacing inconsistencies wrt references.

Fix a few more cases of needless movement warnings

The player could be prompted by exclusions on walls or other impassible
terrain if they tried to move into them (or even while they were unable to
move at all).

Don't run infinitely into walls (Flugkiller)

Trying to perform a movement action that was a no-op (such as walking into
walls) with shift+move still resulted in running happening internally. This
was normally fairly invisible, but resulted in slightly odd behavior with
command repeat (which would abort with a mention about performing 0-time
actions), and could actually result in crashes if travel_key_stop was set
to false when one did so (presumably via causing an infinite loop).

This fixes #4923

Don't re-print items on the player's tile every time they attack (pisaster)

90209b8 resulted in autopickup being requested every time the player
attacked a monster via move_player_action(), which would print items at
their feet if it was not safe to pick them up.

However, some players reporting enjoying the behavior of automatically
picking up autopickup-flagged items at their feet when they finished killed
whatever monster they were fighting, instead of having to step off and back
on again (or hit autoexplore), so now it will request autopickup *either*
if the player actually moves, or it is safe to actually pick things up.

Revert "Rarely allow randomly named graffiti authors."

This reverts commit 782cd2de2604046205dfb1317d8425200ad719eb.

RANDGEN is only translated to a randomly generated name via manual
substitution in name_weapon(); such translation won't work elsewhere.
Rarely allow randomly named graffiti authors.

Split up colour patterns w/ and w/o writing.

So that e.g. alchemy miscasts don't make graffiti appear on either you
or monsters, but Xom's mysterious ways do.

Add another name to graffiti authors.

Reweight the bland names (who knows who's signing these things, anyway?)
so that it's the rarest.

Reweight uses of colour patterns.

Bias them more in favour of single colours and two-colour patterns,
and less in favour of text and graffiti.

Add coloured graffiti to colour patterns.

Add a @graffiti author@ entry to monname.txt, so that we have some names
to sign the graffiti with.
Add more writing nouns to the colour database.

Fix harpoon shot not properly deferring movement finalisation

This could cause a crash if a monster was pulled onto a shaft, but probably
could also be incorrect in other ways.

Fix wizmode monster placement for "the " monsters

An initial "the " needs to be removed for partial monster name matches
to be interpreted properly, so that e.g. "lern" will match "Lernaean
hydra" again.

Simplify and fix how colours are applied to features

We had multiple ways of applying colours to grid features. The first way
was to update the floor and rock wall flavours of the square when
changing the grid colour of the square. This only works for floor and
rock wall features but we want the grid colour to affect other features
such as stone walls. This brings us to the second way used, which was
to use take into account the grid colour of a feature in
`apply_variations` and change its tile accordingly. However, we only did
this for a hardcoded list of tiles which was very hard to tell if it
included all tiles that weren't handled in another way. Neither of
these ways handled animated colours (although the second way could with
a small modification), instead, animated colours were handled when
picking the tile for a feature but only for a hardcoded list of grid
features. This was also done before adding the tile to our tile cache
and as the cache doesn't usualy get invalidated for out of view tiles
this resulted in the colours of out of view tiles not usually animating.
It also happens before we change the tiles used by features based on the
branch and we need to apply the colour after this which resulted in very
hacky code to handle this.

Instead, expand the code in `apply_variations` to handle animated
colours and always try to apply the colour to the tile instead of only
if the tile is on a hardcoded list.

Fix IMB uselessness check

Fixes the case where we want to cast IMB with a friendly monster
between ourself and a hostile one; this should be a warning not a
useless cast.

Move clockroaches out of two sewers, add a new clockroach sewer

The clockroach distribution adjustments in d75a07f resulted in two seperate
Sewer layouts with very long moats for clockroaches to hide behind, in
`sewer_fruit_machine` and `sewer_frog_island_01`. In the abstract, I think
shorter clockroach deep water moats would be fine- we've got plenty of
liquid abuse emphasized in early portals as is, and there's countless ways
to cross such. (Their use of Sandblast also makes their damage quite
unimpressive versus those wearing anything heavier than ring mail.) In
practice, the potentially extremely early nature of Sewers makes it
unfortunately too inconsistent to have much access to much, and the extra
long moats further worsen this (making it hard to retreat, making it
difficult to gauge one's chances to survive, and encouraging waiting very
long times to try and have them wander away).

As such, I have removed clockroaches from both of these sewer layouts, with
mild compensatory buffs to both of them as previously-underperforming
sewers. I have also made a new Sewer layout reliably forefronting this
gimmick with a fair bit more caution (using a much shorter moat with some
minimal reliable cover, limits on clockroach firing counts, and narrow
space for them to roam) and some distinct flavour (with kobolds having a
semi-magical insect collection as earlygame has incidentally picked up).
This should serve as a far better test for how reasonable the gimmick is,
and can be trivially swapped out in the future for other ranged enemies if
these restrictions make the gimmick still too much.

Ever more mutation icons

These are mostly borne from some loose further ideas after I did work on
other icons and tiles for upcoming further bad mutation revisions. Still
going to take a long whiles yet to fully catch up on the remaining three
dozen or so icons without unique icons, alas.

 * Bedevilling: A rejected tentacled monstrosity tile by roctavian,
   combined with ontoclasm's Hexes skill icon and Summon Demon icons.

 * Black Mark: Sastreii's robust mutation icons.

 * Double potion heal: A CC0 potion by Shade combined with ontoclasm's
   local tiles number font and potion of heal wounds icon.

 * In touch with death: Denzi's original mummy tile and Tomb rock tiles,
   combined with Darby's ossuary stone tiles.

 * Naga tail mutation: ontoclasm's mermaid statue, a rejected naga tileset
   by roctavian, and XuaXua's constriction status icon.

 * Sanguine Armour: CanOfWorms's icemail icons, combined with a public
   domain waterfall from the Open Pixel Project.

Make spell name lookup prefer spells that exist

This makes it easier to memorise Freezing Cloud in wizmode, for example.

Remove some broken logic regarding monsters picking up launchers (Acrobat)

Monsters that had damage-dealing spells were supposed to not bother picking
up ranged weapons. This was ancient behavior that ended up broken by
7ec163d (due to the new function using an && instead of an & in one
place...)

However, on reflection, perhaps there is not a sufficiently compelling
reason that conjurer monsters *not* pick up launchers. The original idea
(I presume) was to avoid needless overlap between their spells and another
means of firing damaging projectiles, but we don't stop conjurers from
picking up *wands* and those are even more similar. A handful of monsters
with direct damage spells already can even spawn *with* launchers (eg:
kobold blastminers, deep elf knights), so in the rare chance this happens,
it seems probably fine?

So I am simply removing all logic related to this rather than do a more
exhaustive cleanup of what spells do damage or not. If in future we want
to limit this a bit moreso, there are other ways.

Fix some friendly-fire warnings (Odds)

When af31bf4 refactored code for tracers hitting the player, it
incidentally relied more on the beam's own attitude while ignoring the
agent. However, we don't actually set beam attitude correctly in many
places, so certain spells (including Fire Storm and Freezing Cloud) treated
the player as a hostile target and didn't warn for aiming at yourself.

A more correct solution overall would be to review uses of beam attitude
and generally have beams determine their attitude automatically from their
agent. But in the meantime, this should fix the immediate bug.

This fixes #4915
Add another people name to artefacts.
Add two more orc names.

Fix the tiles for webs sometimes fail to connect

Webs are meant to connect to adjacent webs and solid features. So as
not to leak information that a console player wouldn't know, they can
only be shown connected to other tiles that you have seen or magic
mapped. This means that when a tile first comes into view we need to
redraw the webs around it as they might now connect to it. However,
because we were caching the tile for webs after applying the web
connectivity checks and the tile cache for a square isn't invalidated
when a neighboring square is seen, we sometimes wouldn't redraw. To fix
this move applying the connectivity checks to after we retrieve the tile
from the cache.

Apply branch tile overrides before caching tiles

We were storing tiles in the tile cache without branch overrides and
then applying the overrides every time we accessed the cache. However,
it's fine to apply the overrides to the tiles before storing them in the
cache as we invalidate the whole tile cache when changing levels.

Fix failing Lua monster name test (oops).

Add "name_nocorpse" to the kobold wearing mittens so that it properly
leaves a kobold corpse again.

Fix MF_SUFFIX monster corpse oddity (#4908).

Don't erroneously ignore the suffixes of corpses of monsters with
"n_suf" lacking "n_noc", since we don't do that with corpses of monsters
with "n_adj" lacking "n_noc".

Accordingly, adjust the one redefined monster we currently have that
uses "n_suf" without "n_noc" and leaves a corpse, the spriggan baker, to
use "n_noc" so that it will still properly leave a spriggan corpse
instead of a spriggan baker corpse.

Fix MF_ADJECTIVE monster corpse oddity (#4908).

Don't erroneously display "the" instead of "a" with corpses of monsters
with "n_adj" lacking "n_noc", since we don't do that with corpses of
monsters with "n_suf" lacking "n_noc".
Replace obsolete ref to "wizard" monster in docs.
Fix formicids being able to dig into the level border (and then crash)

Fix inverted logic

Oops >.>

Temporarily change an assert to a no-op (various)

While you.turn_is_over really *should* be false any time
move_player_action() is reached, this assert uncovered some input bugs that
can rarely allow for mouse commands to try performing an action while the
player's turn is theoretically over.

That bug has more widespread consequences than just this function, but is
also non-trivial to fix, so in the meantime let's have this method just
abort instead of crash.

Properly name uniques wrt derived undead (#4908).

Use name_zombie_from_mon(): make a fake monster to hold the name and
name flags we'll get, and then copy them to the mgen_data.

Improve _make_derived_undead()'s naming (#4908).

Make its logic duplicated from name_zombie_from_mon() closer to that of
name_zombie_from_mon(), so that its behaviour is closer to correct (e.g.
it will now only add the usual suffix to uniques instead of both them
and named monsters without the MF_NOCORPSE flag set).

Fix some monster naming wrt MF_NOCORPSE (#4908).

In name_zombie_from_mon() and _make_derived_undead(), if the MF_NOCORPSE
flag is set and the monster's name is discarded, clear all its name
flags as well, so we don't e.g. display spurious spaces for prefixes and
suffixes in the monster's former name.

Fix show_update_at setting a square as not in view

This was mainly causing monster positions to not be correct during force
mores that happen on monster turns in console. This was broken in
commit af76f80

Fix zombified Gehenna SoH losing its name (#4908)

By putting a minor hack into common_name(). It's the only case of a
monster with the same base_type and species where its name shouldn't be
discarded; the other Serpent of Hell varieties have different base
types, and so don't lose their names here.
Fix ?summoning band members disappearing instantly (tekkud)
And #ifdef out insubstantial wisp enum (oops).

Remove insubstantial wisps.

They're not used for anything except as a tile reference for wisp form,
so use their current tile for that directly.

Change its default monster to twister, since it's a vortex-type and it's
nearly the same colour as the original monster.

Remove has_corpse from some more monsters.

Which are non-living, demonic, or either of those. and also
non-spawning due to being genus-only or used just for their tile.

Rename the two versions of name_zombie().

To better differentiate them. name_zombie(mon, mc, mon_name) is now
name_zombie_from_class(), and name_zombie(mon, orig) is now
name_zombie_from_mon().
Fix warnings.

Don't trigger Golubria passages that you just exited

Prior to fec6f05, taking a passage of Golubria didn't perform most
post-move effects. Now that it does, the passage at your *destination* was
being triggered by the movement before the original was removed, resulting
in ping-ponging back and forth between them until the stack overflowed.

Now, the movement from Golubria cannot trigger other Golubria traps.

This fixes #4911

Slightly reorder trap triggering in finalise_movement()

Traps are (at least currently) the only part of finalise_movement() that
can itself result in moving an actor (and a recursive call to
finalise_movement()).

Skip remaining parts of the function if the player was moved, to avoid
some theoretically-dubious semantics. Much of the code afterward was
relative to the player's 'new' position instead of their old one anyway,
and whatever trap-triggered movement happened should have done its own
cleanup.

(I am not certain if a meaningful bug was possible from this in practice
yet, but I can imagine future ones.)

Fix Vaults:4 down stairs description (acrobat3)

We were trying to override the description for stone down stairs in
Vaults:4 to be metal stairs in the layout code for Vaults. However,
the vaults placed by the layout have their own set of overrides which
are used instead. Instead of trying to use vault description overrides,
special case stone down stairs in `_base_feature_desc` similar to what
we do for rock walls in Pandemonium.

Fixes #4896

Fix clear_to_end_of_line crashing on windows

It isn't meant to change the cursor position so we were using
`save_cursor_pos` to prevent this. However, `save_cursor_pos` requires
a valid cursor position and it should be fine to call
`clear_to_end_of_line` with the cursor at the character just after the
end of line which isn't valid.
Fix wording.
Clarify comment.

Fix a crash with monsters escaping constriction

When monsters escaped ranged constriction forcibly, the codepath resulted
in deleting ENCH_CONSTRICTED in the middle of actor::stop_constricting(),
potentially invalidating a reference still being used. This should
hopefully fix that.

Don't warn players about moving onto traps under enemies (not_that_greg)

Since the movement action won't actually move you there.
Remove unneeded blank line.

Mention spider form's new immunity to webs.

In the spider talisman's description.

Remove an obsolete barbs rampage warning

Following 90209b8f76, rampage only deals barbs damage once no matter the
distance travelled, so we no longer need a special-cased prompt message
about huge barbs damage here.

Rewrite move_player_action and general rampage movement handling

The way rampage movement was implemented was somewhat brittle and resulted
in a handful of inconsistencies (that have become even more obvious now
that players can stack rampage to move multiple tiles at once). Internally,
it performed an 'instant' movement directly to the second-last tile of the
full rampage, then attempted to do a single normal movement in that same
direction. This resulted in a number of issues:
 -Rampaging would skip over traps on any but the final two tiles (unless
  you were attacking a monster, in which case it would skip over all traps
  except the final one)
 -The time spent moving when crossing slow terrain would depend very
  idiosyncratically on what *order* the terrain was encountered in.
 -Whether you would whirlwind a monster you appeared to pass alongside
  varied based on precisely how distant you were from them - if you
  'jumped' too far, you would not attack them at all, despite arriving
  beside them.
 -If the initial movement displaced the player somehow (such as a dispersal
  trap), the second movement would still automatically procede from the
  player's new location; it was possible to perform dangerous attacks
  without a prompt this way, or accidentally open runed doors (or even
  move at instant speed movement if you happened to bump into a neutral
  monster).
 -Rampage would jump 'over' invisible monsters, unless they were at the
  player's destination, in which case the player would take only a single
  step and stop (no matter how far away the invisible monster was).

On top of all this, there were checks needed in many places to make sure
the movement actually took time if the player was interrupted before the
'normal' movement could happen.

move_player_action() (with which it was deeply entwined) is also very old
code that has had so many additions and removals over the decades that the
resulting logic was needlessly difficult to follow (and contained a lot of
highly dubious statements like resetting local variables immediately before
exiting...)

This commit is an attempt to clean up both, rewriting move_player_action()
to be clearer, while making rampaging more of a first-class citizen within
it. Rampaging now actually performs an arbitrary number of individual steps
in sequence (rather than one instant jump and one normal move). Anything
that would stop the player's ability to move in the middle will cancel the
rest of the sequence (including arriving somewhere unexpected). The
movement cost of the rampage is calculated as the *average* movement cost
of all steps along the movement path, and it now only triggers barbs and
sticky flame shake-off a single time (instead of often precisely twice, no
matter the distance travelled).

In addition, this fixes several other issues with move_player_action():
 -Fungus form was permitted to move in sight of enemies, so long as this
  was done by swapping with something.
 -Winding a clockwork bee took no time (!)
 -Shallow water could be entered at normal speed, but *exiting* it was slow
  (Possibly unknowingly changed by d469af4, whose reasons for reordering
  the relevant no longer apply to the current version of pursuit attacks)
 -Martial attacks did not reset the player's berserk non-attack penalty
  properly (merely pausing it temporarily).

Finally, this makes it possible to perform martial attacks while digging.
This interaction was probably deliberate, but very obscure and doesn't feel
like an exception worth preserving; if dig-lunge-stabbing really is too
strong, we can always make the noise digging already does alert adjacent
things first.

Fix can_pass_through() for wall-walking monsters (Sergey)

can_pass_through() returned false for anything *but* walls for
wall-walkers, resulting in a handful of incorrect behaviors, which
included at least:
 -Wall-walkers were unable to swap with other monsters on open ground
 -They could not be pulled by harpoon shot
 -Transference would fail on them

There were fewer consequences for this than one might expect, as
monster_habitable_grid() and similar functions controlled most of this sort
of thing. (In fact, there are already comments that the difference between
the two ought to be refactored in future....)

Remove a misleading parameter from wielded_weapon_check()

Only the player's mainhand weapon was passed to this function, but it would
pull out the player's offhand weapon on its own. Since literally every
single call of this function passes you.weapon() as the first parameter,
remove that parameter entirely and obtain it inside the function just as is
done for offhand weapons.
Fix the Diminished Spells status missing a description (Snakku)
Fix a tiny typo

Don't allow monsters bound in place to break free of constriction

The player needs to be able to move in order to try pulling away from
constriction, and it seems sensible to me that monsters also do.

Fix monsters polymorphed into a naturally warded monster not having warding

It looks to me like stuff like this probably ought to be handled inside
define_monster() in the first place, but there's always a chance that
there's a valid reason and I'm not going to spend the time required to
investigate properly at this moment.

Allow Robin to throw hobgoblins

It was fairly opaque that they could not (their Battlecry works on them!)
and not even clear that it was originally intended, either.

Change constriction range rules slightly

It is now possible to perform a constricting melee attack against
non-adjacent targets if your auxes have reaching (such as from aqua form).

Melee constriction can now be maintained while moving, so long as you
don't move further away from the constrictee. (In most cases, this simply
means you are allowed to sidestep around a constricted monster. In aqua
form's case, it very specifically allows you to approach but *not* retreat,
to avoid tedious kiting behavior of grabbing a monster, stepping back to
full reaching distance while it is stuck in place, and repeating ad
nauseum.)

Fix a few monster pathfinding issues

Broken by 04fd3a2 , monsters would consider all other monsters impassible
and also often fail to realize they could open doors.

Some players attributed the former behavior to giving monsters more
interesting 'flanking' behavior, but in my testing it did not actually seem
to result in that very much more often than the previous code (but would
sometimes get monsters stuck in place, especially with groups of allies).

Refactor all actor movement code

There were a variety of different functions that existed to move the
player (or monsters), whose semantics differed in ways that were not always
immediately clear (eg: you.move_to_pos() vs. you.moveto() vs.
move_player_to_grid())

Moreover, a lot of effects that were expected to happen as part of movement
(or immediately afterward) required calling different sets of methods
manually - for instance, to apply traps or break Ramparts or shake off
sticky flame. Because actors are moved in many, many different functions,
there were quite a lot of oversights regarding what sort of post-movement
cleanup should happen after a given movement. For instance, forgetting to
trigger traps after particular movements was a perpetually reoccuring bug
that still existed in at least a dozen places, by my count.

This is an attempt to clarify movement functions, attain more consistency
in post-move effects, and make such oversights less likely in the future.

There is now a single standard movement function, actor::move_to(), which
should be used in virtually all cases. It takes a set of movement flags as
an argument, which defines the *semantics* of the movement (eg: whether it
was deliberate, a translocation, etc.) so that post-movement effects can
be handled in a consistent way: the caller states what type of movement it
is, and the code itself will ensure that the proper cleanup is done for
that type of movement.

Traps, location effects, cancelling of delays, handling barbs, and almost
everything of that nature is now handled via actor::finalise_movement(),
which is called by ::move_to() by default, but can be deferred to a later
time with a single argument. There are many cases where an actor must move,
do something, and only *then* have traps trigger. Rather than selecting a
specific movement function, manually remembering their old position, and
then remembering to call an appropriate collection of post-movement
functions afterward, the new idiom in these cases is simply:
 -Call move_to() with appropriate flags and deferred=true
 -Call finalise_movement() afterward (which itself keeps track of the
  original position).

There will be some minor changes from this commit to which movements
trigger which post-movement effects (since there were a multitude of bugs
or arguable-bugs), but there should be much more consistency now, and
easier use in future.

(One minor nit is that teleport code is not comprehensive about setting
MV_DELIBERATE for teleports that are agentive, since the teleport codepaths
are still tangled. However, for the moment, MV_DELIBERATE does not do
anything much while MV_TRANSLOCATION is also true, so I don't think there
will be any negative effects. Something to maybe untangle in future,
though.)

Don't sometimes fail to place temp shallow water in Shoals

Due to tides code, there was a change that if temp shallow water was placed
near where tides were currently receding, it would immediately be converted
back to dry land by the time the player could even see it.

Now temporary terrain should be left untouched by the tides.

Change / simplify the Engulf status

Engulfing (as done by water elementals) had a handful of extant bugs, and
also some tangled code semantics whereby ::clear_far_engulf() had a
different meaning when called on monsters versus players. This would be
fixable, but it's unclear how effective the current mechanic actually is,
so after some discussion with other devs, I have opted to replace it with
a simpler effect and fold the Waterlogged status together with it.

Now named Flooded, this provides the current Waterlogged silence effect as
well as a small amount of ongoing asphyxiation damage. It is never applied
to non-air-breathers (instead of the mildly confusing 'you're engulfed but
don't actually suffer any ill effects because of it' status that previously
existed) and cleared immediately if you stop needing air.

Effects that previously engulfed now apply a few turns of Flooded instead
(and existing effects that applied Waterlogged now also apply Flooded).
Phial's direct damage is reduced significantly in exchange for the new DoT
that accompanies its silence (weak though it is). The Engulf mutation now
applies on damageless hits (better mirroring monsters that apply it).

In many situations, this may make the silence effect from water elementals
and void oozes more dangerous than before, though at least some amount of
this is intentional: being able to reliably shake off the effect with a
single turn of movement meant that it was typically only dangerous in the
very worst of situations or when literally surrounded. Now, it may be
relevant more often (though hopefully not overly so; I admit some mild
concerns about melee pursuit attacks).

For now, I opted for flat fixed damage on the effect (2d5 versus players
and 3d2 against monsters). It is possible it would be better to have its
damage depend in some manner upon the source of the flooding, but hopefully
this is functional for now.

Remove a useless function

Mostly made irrelevant by 77787f6 but accidentally left around (and
making it so that some options in the list could never actually be picked
anyway...). Its logic was highly dubious in the first place (nothing about
'pouncing' directly implies webbing, we've already had non-poison stings
for ages, etc.)

Generalise player silence checks a little

Make ::is_silenced() an actor method instead of just a monster one, and
apply similar logic to fold in checks for Engulf into the player one
(instead of doing these manually in multiple places and overlooking a few).

(Note that this does not replace use of silenced(you.pos()) altogether,
since that checks whether sound can exist at the player's position, not
whether the player themselves can make any. This matters for hearing, and
also things like the Singing Sword, which cares not for whether you are
currently drowning.)

Don't let orbs of destruction swap places with battlespheres

An obscure special-case that was presumably trying to emulate the ability
for the player to fire projectiles through their own battlesphere, however
they do not behave this way for other allies you can normally shoot through
(eg: ancestors or Fedhas plants) and I think it would sometimes be
confusing if they actually *did* displace those allies, so let's remove
this. (I suspect nobody will even notice.)

Fix a few oddities with fear/mesmerise and adjust messages

For some reason (perhaps ancient copy-paste from siren code), fear on the
player would immediately break if either the player or the monster in
question became silenced. (There wasn't even a check to stop the monster
from re-fearing you in this case, but it would again immediately break.)

This is silly and has been removed from both fear and non-siren mesmerism.

I have also edited a variety of messages for mesmerisers losing their hold
on the player. (Fun fact: many of the existing ones were literally
unreachable from the moment they were added by 8333f45 due to overlooking
an early return at the start of the function *unless* you were a siren.

Remove spflag::harms_area

It is no longer needed since the changes to Sanctuary.

Slightly refactor torment_cell

It is no longer structured somewhat oddly specifically so that it could
torment the player and also a monster standing on the player's tile at the
same time.

(The monsters the player can overlap with are generally torment-immune
anyway, but this concept of affecting both 'the player and a monster they
might be standing on' is already not done in countless places and is very
difficult to enforce, so I think it's better to work for consistency in
the opposite direction, and assume the player takes all the heat for
whatever it's standing on top of.)
Fix damage punctuation for boulders hitting things (Planckenstein)

Fix some oddnesses with attacking while confused

If the player is stumbling around in confusion and attempted to attack an
ally that could not be harmed (eg: an ancestor), that attempt to take no
time, essentially allowing the player to freely reroll until they went
somewhere else.

Additionally, if they were wielding an unrand that might prompt for hurting
other allies (eg: the Arc Blade), this prompt would still be given while
confused, and aborting would consume no time. This allowed the player to
reroll their confused movement until they picked some step that did not
contain a monster.

Now, no prompts should be given for attacks while confused (beyond the
warning about moving while confused at all), and time should be consumed as
normal if the player was too impaired to realize their attack was
pointless.

Remove a (hopefully) unnecessary safety hack

There are multiple levels of protection already in place to regress harmful
beams from friendly monsters before they hit the player (even if an ally
should somehow end up targeting the player directly with one, which
probably also can't happen by normal means).

Heavily refactor handling of Sanctuary, adjust mechanics somewhat

Due to Crawl's code structure (and the many, many different codepaths by
which offensive actions could be taken by the player or monsters),
Sanctuary required an enormous number of special cases and there were still
a considerable number of oversights and arguably broken behaviors involved
with it. A partial list includes:
 -The player could still take damage when inside a Sanctuary from several
  spells, including: Polar Vortex, Plasma Beam, Manifold Assault, Foxfire
  (if you were on the edges of the sanctuary), OTR, Scorch, and
  Seismic Stomp. (This list grows even larger if a monster was targeting
  something other than the player.)
 -Monsters could still directly attack a player inside a sanctuary in some
  scenarios (despite several bits of code directly trying to stop this)
 -Allied monsters could attack other monsters even while both were inside
  the sanctuary.
 -Monsters would refuse to fire most beams while the player was in a
  sanctuary, even if those beams were neither originating from nor aimed at
  anything inside the sanctuary.
 -Even friendly monstes were unable to enter a sanctuary if they were
  outside it when it was first made.
 -Alarmingly, monsters were forbidden from casting many, many AoE spells
  so long as a sanctuary existed on the floor, regardless of whether the
  player was in it (or indeed, whether it was even in sight of them). This
  included things like Symbol of Torment, Call Down Damnation, Fire Storm,
  Chain Lightning, Blink Allies Encircling, Irradiate, and many, many more.
 -Almost certainly more things that I have since forgotten while working on
  this....

This commit attempts to run many more things through could_harm() to
outright prevent things inside a sanctuary from being harmed by even
idiosyncratic AoE effects, as well as removing many now-redundant sanctuary
checks, and hopefully making sanctuary-related oversights harder to make in
future. (There are admittedly still a lot of special-cases left, but
meaningfully fewer.)

The desired end behavior of this change:
 -Actors inside a sanctuary cannot be harmed by any means
 -The player cannot harm anyone, anywhere, so long as they themselves are
  inside a sanctuary
 -Monsters are allowed to cast spells within a sanctuary, so long as they
  are non-offensive (including healing, buffs, and translocations)
 -Non-aligned actors are no longer allowed to swap with each other inside
  a sanctuary. (The fact that the player could swap position with hostile
  monsters was opaque and unexpected behavior, and I think also no longer
  necessary in the new system).

As an example consequence, the player casting Shatter inside a sanctuary
will injure nothing. If they are outside of a sanctuary, it will be able to
injure anything *not* in a sanctuary (without causing damage to those
inside it).

Since it should no longer be possible to cause harm to anything within a
sanctuary, penance for doing so (and associated warnings) has also been
removed.

Realize we can't place hostile monsters in sanctuaries earlier

The check that prevented non-friendly monsters from being created inside
a sanctuary happened *after* the spot to create a monster was randomly
selected, meaning that summon spells would irregularly fail (and produce
puffs of smoke) if used somewhere in the area of a sanctuary.

Instead, try to find a space outside the sanctuary first.

(This also allows wizmode to create monsters inside of sanctuaries instead
of also randomly failing.)

Allow Gloom to pass through grates

It's hard to imagine something less impeded by metal bars than 'gloom'.

Remove some code handling player-cast glaciate

This hasn't been player-castable for many years and that seems unlikely to
change any time soon.

Allow a few more spells to work with Aphotic Marionette

Due to some recent changes (and some older ones), several spells that were
previously non-functional can now do something useful, so allow them to be
used.

Refactor never_harm_monster to be more general

A follow-up to 1dcf16d that is a bit more generalised, this extends the
same style of logic used to control the player shooting through special
allies to actors in general. shoot_through_monster() is now
shoot_though_actor(), never_harm_monster() is now could_harm() (with
inverted semantics), with could_harm_enemy() being added as shorthand that
folds in a common mons_aligned() check (ie: 'Is a given actor an enemy we
could harm?'

Overall, this requires fewer casts, but also allows (among other things)
marionettes to realize at higher level that they cannot harm the player,
allowing several monster spells to be cast via marionette more properly
than they used to be. Also, this is an important first step towards some
changes to Sanctuary handling in a subsequent commit.

I have also removed a number of redundant checks in player prompts which
are now already handled by bad_attack().

Attribute clouds made by marionettes to the player

This very slightly improves the XP the player would gain from things dying
to these clouds, but more significantly allows spectral mist made by
marionettes to produce spectrals belonging to the player.

Fix Fire Storm tracer sometimes hitting the player anyway

Fire Storm's radius is randomly rolled each time it is cast, but this meant
that the tracer could roll radius 2, think the player was out of range, and
then roll radius 3 on the actual spell cast, potentially blasting any
friendlies standing 3 tiles away (including the player).

Now, the tracer should always act as if it *might* explode with radius 3.
(Since monsters always aim the explosion at a real target, this doesn't
risk them entirely whiffing the spell.) Any similarly variable explosions
that monsters use should get similar treatment, but I can't think of any
that still exist at the moment.

Remove a long-unneeded special-case

Even before recent tracer changes, Hep ancestors have been able to shoot
harmlessly through the player for years now.

Make friendly monsters entirely unwilling to catch the player in explosions

There's been a gradual push over the years to make allies entirely safe to
the player (or at least those allies that are not naturally expected to be
dangerous, like blazeheart golems or a ball lightning servitor), with
changes like cae8a03 and 330b8c2 removing many past ways to get blasted by
your own summons.

However, there was no special protection against explosive beams, merely
relying on the fact that default foe_ratio made it very unlikely an ally
would consider blasting you. Nonetheless, in rare situations, it was still
*possible* for an ally to fireball your face. Probably this isn't worth
generally preserving, and we can use a more sure-fire way to prevent allies
from choosing to damage you by directly vetoing harmful beams that would
hit the player at all.

It does make me a *little* sad to nerf the scary and somewhat iconic
double-edged nature of early Nem pan lord summons, but if we want to
preserve some of that for a few effects, it probably makes more sense to
use other (and more transparent) means.

Don't prevent allies you can shoot through from getting frenzied

Not that one is terribly likely to run into a monster that *can* frenzy
them at the moment, but it feels like this blanket exception is a little
weird.

(To be clear, casting Discord yourself will still ignore them; this only
affects hostile attempts to frenzy your allies.)

Make spider form immune to webs

A shocking oversight, really.

Majorly refactor handling of being caught in nets/webs

The code underlying throwing nets was complex and brittle, and relied on
a combination of both a status effect AND an actual throwing net item being
on the ground at the actor's feet, with particular properties to mark it
'fixed in place'. Many different parts of the codebase had to understand
that this net wasn't a 'normal' item and should not be interacted with like
a normal item, and even after all that it was sometimes possible to
disconnect the two and leave a net 'stuck' to the ground.

Webs likewise relied on the presence of a web trap at the actor's feet
(even when caused by spells like Ensnare). The effect of this was more
subtle, but meant that an entity ensnared on any tile besides plain floor
would always succeed on its next escape check, and print no message for
doing so.

This commit removes all reliance on net items on the floor (or real web
traps) to make the corresponding status effect work. Whether an actor is
trapped in a real net is stored in a prop, and escaping from the net can
simply create a fresh net item on the floor at the actor's feet when
appropriate. This allows for far more flexibility, and is less error-prone.
Single-use webs are also destroyed upon triggering, rather than upon
escaping, similarly reducing cleanup issues.

A small functional change is that !lignification no longer escapes from
webs and nets, and turning into a dragon no longer escapes from nets. The
latter is a leftover from when nets couldn't hold giant monsters, but it's
unclear why the former behavior existed at all.

(This also fixes some broken behavior with one of Xom's swap effects, which
was intended to switch the net/web status of the player and a monster, but
due to the brittleness of net code, would stick the player in an fake
web instead of a net anyway.)

Replace the last remaining use of actor::shove()

push_or_teleport_actor_from() performed a very similar function and was
used more widely.

(In fact, the last usage of monster::shove() was already removed 11 years
ago by cd26887 !)

Tweak behavior of push_or_teleport_actor_from()

This method (used mostly for pushing actors out of solid terrain upon
terrain changes) had slightly weird behavior in that it pushed in a random
direction if there was a free adjacent space, but then would be push
non-randomly up to 7 tiles further than that, and then would teleport
randomly if even that failed. While unlikely, there is a very small chance
for the teleport to fail to move the player, so let's ensure this cannot
happen by iterating exhaustively (and fully randomly) instead.

Also, it was theoretically possible to displace the player onto liquids
they couldn't inhabit. I'm not sure it was possible to encounter this in
a real game, as nearly the only way to trigger this on yourself involved
flying over hellfire mortar lava as it sealed up (meaning lava was certain
to be fine).
